Award.AwardTitle: ABR: Novel Glycoprotein Hormone, Signaling Mechanisms, and Transcriptome Profiling in a Basal Vertebrate
Award.AbstractNarration: This research will investigate the brain and pituitary glycoprotein hormones and respective receptors that regulate reproduction in a the basal vertebrate, the sea lamprey. Lampreys have an ancestral unique pituitary glycoprotein hormone (GpH) not found in any other vertebrate. This project will examine the origin and/or divergence of the pituitary glycoprotein-hormone-receptor families and the molecular mechanisms and dynamics of pituitary GpH signaling. Results will tell whether these hormones share common functional and developmental features with the other hormones found in all other vertebrates. This project will provide key information in neuroscience, neuroendocrinology, molecular biology and vertebrate biology, and it will provide training oppportunities for postdocs, undergraduates and graduate students in these areas. Gaining a further understanding of reproductive hormones and their respective receptors, interactions with neurotransmitters and testing analogs will be critical for development of novel strategies for improving and controlling reproduction. The PI as Director of the Center for Molecular and Comparative Endocrinology (CME) facilitates worldwide and local collaborations, laboratory exchange visits and chalk talks that yield benefits leading to increased student/postdoc engagement in the research community. Outreach activities are varied and broad, including public talks and collaborating with a Biotechnology Program at a local community college. A lamprey brain atlas will also be developed as an interactive neuroanatomy digital resource to be available for the scientific community. The PI and members of the laboratory are involved with an international group of 47 scientists who are annotating the lamprey genome. The data generated through the research will consist of nucleotide and protein sequences, phylogenetic analysis, graphs, three-dimensional structures of the receptors, reconstructed microscopic images, photographs, and hand-recorded observations, and will be made available to qualified parties by the PI so long as such a request does not compromise intellectual property interests, interfere with publication, invade subject privacy, or betray confidentiality.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Vertebrate reproduction is regulated by a hierarchically organized endocrine system, known as the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal (HPG) axis, which is highly conserved across all vertebrates.  Through our research and discoveries, we have provided substantial evidence that the hypothalamic-pituitary (HP) system, which is specific to vertebrates, is considered to be an evolutionary innovation that emerged prior to or during the differentiation of the ancestral jawless vertebrates (agnathans) leading to the neuroendocrine control of many complex functions (Sower, 2018, Gen Comp Endocrinol). Hagfish and lampreys are the only two surviving members of the oldest lineage of vertebrates, the agnathans. Vertebrates are classified into two major groups, the gnathostomes (jawed vertebrates) and the agnathans (jawless vertebrates). Gnathostomes constitute all other living vertebrates including the bony and cartilaginous fishes and the tetrapods. 

Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), a small brain (hypothalamic) peptide, is the master control and regulator of reproduction in all vertebrates via the pituitary. There are slightly different structures of this conserved peptide in vertebrates. Generally, jawed vertebrates have one or two hypothalamic (brain) GnRHs while lampreys have three hypothalamic GnRHs called lamprey GnRH-I, -II, and -III. In gnathostomes, there are three classical pituitary glycoprotein hormones (luteinizing hormone, LH; follicle stimulating hormone, FSH; and thyrotropin, TSH) interacting specifically with three receptors, LH-R, FSH-R, and TSH-R, respectively. In general, FSH and LH regulate gonadal activity and TSH regulates thyroidal activity. In contrast to gnathostomes, we hypothesize from our findings that lampreys only have two heterodimeric pituitary glycoprotein hormones, lamprey glycoprotein hormone (lGpH) and thyrostimulin, and two lamprey glycoprotein hormone receptors (lGpH-R I and -R II). Our existing data also suggest the existence of a primitive, overlapping yet functional hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal (HPG) and HP-thyroidal (HPT) endocrine systems in lampreys. The study of basal vertebrates provides promising models for understanding the evolution of the hypothalamic-pituitary-thyroidal and gonadal axes in vertebrates. We hypothesize that the glycoprotein hormone/glycoprotein hormone receptor systems emerged as a link between the neuroendocrine and peripheral control levels during the early stages of gnathostome divergence. Our discovery of a functional HPG axis in lamprey by comprehensive biochemical, molecular, physiological and phylogenetic studies has provided important clues for understanding the forces that ensured a common organization of the hypothalamus and pituitary as essential regulatory systems in all vertebrates. 

In summary, my laboratory along with my collaborators have been the driving force in elucidating the lamprey neuroendocrine system. My laboratory provided an environment to actively engage and encourage undergraduate students, graduate students and postdoctoral associates to achieve his or her maximum potential. Two elements of becoming a highly productive researcher are (1) opportunities for development of skills required for competence in research, writing, and publication and (2) a network of collegial relationships within and outside the institution, often through scientific meetings and collaborations. The PI as Director of the Center for Molecular and Comparative Endocrinology facilitated worldwide and local collaborations, laboratory exchange visits and chalk talks that yielded benefits leading to increased student/postdoc engagement in the research community. My laboratory hosted Professor Masumi Nozaki and his PhD student from Niigata University, Japan (two visits), Professsor Berta Levavi-Sivan from Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Israel (three visits) and Professor Dan Larhammar, University of Sweden as well as other US visiting scientists. Two graduate students spent two to four months in the laboratory of Professor Levavi-Sivan in Israel, engaged in collaborative research.The research during the grant period involved the training of five graduate students, fourteen undergraduate students, and four postdoctoral/visiting scholars including six from underrepresented groups. The outcomes of this grant led to twenty-three full-refereed publications/book chapters. Nineteen of these publications have been co-authored by graduate students, postdoctoral associates, collaborators and/or undergraduate students. The PI, postdocs, undergraduate and graduate students presented 44-invited symposium speaker & oral presentations and posters at various conferences including international presentations in France, Spain, Israel, Japan, Sweden and Canada.  Network activities included public talks, local presentations and/or workshops with parents of K-12 students and K-12 students. We hosted and trained high school students in basic laboratory techniques during the summer from the Seacoast Science Technology program. All these activities included people from underrepresented groups. Upon request, the PI has provided lamprey tissues, cDNA, hormone antisera and peptides to more than 15 investigators world-wide.
